content: An independent commission called the "Commission on America and its Veterans" is established in the executive branch. After more than a decade of war, the United States needs a more comprehensive process for welcoming and reintegrating members of the Armed Forces back into society. There are gaps in support for veterans that need to be addressed, and the country must stay connected with their experiences in war and upon returning. Veterans make significant contributions to society, but many also face ongoing psychological challenges. The United States needs a whole-of-society approach to improve veterans' position in society, address ongoing psychological trauma, challenges with employment, crime, and dislocation. It is crucial to support veterans, their families, and communities in a way that helps them reintegrate successfully. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF COMMISSION. The Commission is required to submit reports to the President and Congress by specific dates, suggesting ceremonies to acknowledge wars, heroism of Armed Forces members, and the costs of wars. They must also report on deficiencies in welcoming back Armed Forces members, studying the reintegration experience on members, families, and communities. The Commission will convene conversations nationwide to discuss the impact of war on members, families, and communities, focusing on reintegration experiences and the gap between military, veterans, and civilian life. Starting 180 days after the enactment of the Act, regular discussions will be held. The Commission will submit recommendations to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs on the Office of Armed Services and Veterans Public Outreach, focusing on facilitating interactions between members of the Armed Forces, veterans, and civilians, especially with young people. Interim reports may also be submitted to the President and Congress with agreed-upon findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission consists of 18 members appointed by various officials, with specific qualifications required. The Commission shall hold its initial meeting within 60 days of the enactment of the Act, with subsequent meetings called by the chairman or majority of members. Ten members constitute a quorum. The Commission may establish rules for its business conduct, with ten members constituting a quorum. The Commission has the power to establish rules for its business conduct, with ten members needed for a quorum. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. They must hold hearings in each state and may enter into contracts to fulfill their responsibilities. Additionally, the Commission can obtain information directly from federal agencies. The Commission can obtain necessary information from federal agencies to carry out its responsibilities under the Act. The General Services Administration will provide administrative support services upon request, and other departments and agencies will also offer assistance as needed. The Commission can receive services, funds, facilities, staff, and support from US departments or agencies as needed. They can also accept gifts, bequests, or devises of services or property for their work. Additionally, the Commission can use the US mails like other government entities. The Commission can receive staff support as needed. The chairman appoints staff and sets their compensation without following standard government employment rules. The staff director and necessary personnel are appointed to help the Commission fulfill its responsibilities. The compensation cannot exceed a certain level. The executive director and employees of the Commission are federal employees under title 5, United States Code. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission can procure expert and consultant services at rates not exceeding level IV of the Executive. The Commission can accept voluntary services and use uncompensated services as needed, regardless of section 1342 of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 7. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission will hold public meetings, release public reports, and conduct public hearings in a manner that protects sensitive information. SEC. 8. The Commission's termination is specified. The Commission will terminate on May 31, 2016, and may use the 60-day period before termination for concluding activities and providing testimony to Congress. Additionally, an Office of Armed Services and Veterans Public Outreach will be established. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish an Office of Armed Services and Veterans Public Outreach to facilitate interactions between veterans, members of the Armed Forces, and civilians, particularly young people, to share their stories and experiences. SEC. 10. FUNDING. This Act does not increase authorized appropriations for any fiscal year. SEC. 11. VETERAN DEFINED. The term "veteran" is defined as in section 101(2) of title 38, United States Code.
